moves.8. Nb5:
advances, to set trap
if rook to b8, knight to c7 free pawn
if pawn to c6, knight to c7 pinning king to rook
moves.10... Bh6: tries trade, needs room to work
moves.11. d5:
big mistake
miscalculated pawn trade (c pawn takes white d pawn, white bishop takes a7)
moves.11... Bxe3: trades bishops, resulting in free pawn
moves.12... Ngf6:
decides instead to strengthen position, and make it a trade
probably a mistake
moves.13. Nf3: white should have traded, but wanted to set up kingside castling position
moves.13... Ng4:
leave the pawn for something better
if he trades the pawn, queen to e3 resulting in a 1 point gain trade, and killing center defence
moves.14. Nd4: tries to block, and set up favorable c6 trade with same piece
moves.16. Qe2: good move, also could have taken rook
moves.16... Rxe2+: best trade possible at this point
moves.20. Rf1: oops, in more than one way
moves.21. Kxf1: you messed that one up white
moves.23... Bc4:
pinns bishop to king
good trade
moves.24. a5:
continues to advance pawns
until knight can move it's sort of a tie
moves.30... g4:
very good move
supports the f pawn, when it goes for the king, and promotion
moves.32... gxf3+: this forces white king to retreat
moves.34. b7: he wants to promote that pawn at all costs
moves.34... dxc2: pawn ready to promote, with another in reserve
moves.35... c1=Q+: does same, must keep white king in constant check, until rook can be pinned to have a chance
moves.36... Qd2+: black must continue to check, until he can get the rook in his diagonal view
